title: Why do you folks buy skins
body:
In rare instances do I find skins useful. I like yasuos project skin because it makes a noticeable sound each hit and helps you get an idea if youre landing your Q's, etc. 

Some others like teemo omega squad make a much more noticable sound on shrooms and blinding darts.


But I probably wouldnt spend 20 bucks on a skin. Why? Wouldnt you rather purchase champions on sale. spend the IP on runes, and save urself the time to earn the money for those 6300 IP champs?


Seriously save the money and go buy yourself an icecream, or movie tickets for 2, or a blowjob or something

Thats the amount of time i roughly play League per day.

Like... I don't understand running. Running sucks. Personally I just bicycle to work every day, since is only 3.8 miles away. Gets me 40 minutes of cardio every day at the cost of about 8 minutes increased commute each way.

To anchor me to my account deeper so I never have incentive to make another account just to get out of bronze and not suffer the MMR I've been digging since S1.
getting out of bronze is quite simple really.
I am not having this conversation.
You dont have to, but spending that money on a boost instead of skins may be a better use of your money my friend

Correction, I am having this conversation.
First off, it is a known and accepted fact that players who are good enough to get out of bronze eventually do so. I can give you an entire encyclopedia of my consistent mistakes that keep me from climbing. Like, I'm aware of why I have only ever entered promos to Silver 5 one time and failed it. Here's just the tip of the iceberg.
- I never buy Mercurial Scimitar.
- I am bad with using Mikael's Crucible's active on allies with perfect timing.
- I forget to upgrade my trinket.
- I rely on my teammates to assist me in making plays.
- I am bad at cheesing, therefore end up feeding from the outplay.
- I am bad at csing under the turret.
- I am especially bad at missclicking the wrong champion in clutch situations.
- I do not jungle. When I do, I'm horrible at it.
- I do not watch my replays to learn from my mistakes.
- I sometimes completely forget to buy boots.
- I don't understand some matchups and how they beat me so fast.
- I don't keep myself updated on what champions need to rush what from a patch-to-patch basis.
- I expect too much from my teammates.

That being said, I have been told that I have a gold-level knowledge base. I know how to kite well, I know where to ward, why, and when. I can almost always tell whether the enemy team is doing dragon or not if it's not warded. I can also tell if they're sneaking a baron without it being warded. I have a 6th sense when I'm about to get ganked from behind my tower, and who's doing it. (That's general champion knowledge at work obviously.) I press tab and try my best to keep up with the enemy's items, and actively build against them.

Barring that, I sometimes pick one support, then another without changing runes and masteries. I am also not completely clear on why which support picks which Keystone. This knowledge can't translate into carrying myself out of Bronze because I don't know what order I need to work on things is. I've managed to stay out of Bronze V for a very, very long time, so I'm assuming that's a sign I've improved somehow, some way. Recently, I've been able to stick closer to Bronze II, and if I end up Bronze IV, I always win my promos to III and rush up back, sailing through promos to II. I can tell I'm improving. My cs averages have gotten higher, my accuracy closer, my movement prediction more precise, and my reaction time quicker. Only when I improve the things I listed above on a consistent basis will I ever hope to win my promos to Silver V. God knows what I'll have to learn I'm bad at after that.

If you know all these things then you just need to implement them to get out of bronze. 

Mercurial scimitar is a good item for adcs and some assassins like yi. 

The reason many players are in bronze after so many years is the fact they cant implement these things. Anyone can read tips online but having the brain power to implement them is limited

Limited brain power? You mean the brain power I use on my grammar, sentence structure, use of Oxford commas, and effort to use correct punctuation? No but seriously...
I don't know what to work on first, what to focus on first. I try to nip in the bud certain issues, but I end up trading one issue for another. What in that list do you suggest I work on first and foremost?

Well grammar and punctuation Isn't going to help in league. 

It is important to remember that league isnt a team death match and your goal is to some how get to that nexus in the end. How you do it, is important.

If a team mate is constantly getting gang banged by 4-5 people in another lane that might sound like bad news, to you, and maybe that person IS an idiot, but that leaves two lanes open for you guys to annihilate. 

Generally speaking its okay to go Back and save yourself a death and comeback with full health rather than risk feeding them a death

Try playing with your gold level or higher friends and learn to deal with pressure in maps.

Then go to your own ranked account and focus on early game champs. When I play bronze matches with my girlfriend I usually ban trundle{{champion:48}}  and sometimes yi.{{champion:11}}  I take volibear Jg.{{champion:106}} 

You say youre poor at jg but I ask why? Why do you think you do badly at jungle?
Is it because youre not ganking, is it because youre not taking drags? The purpose of the jungle early game is to tilt the game into the teams favor. So if your team is dominating at 10 minutes you probably shouldnt be wasting a minute and half at drag. Just push carefully. 

Learn how to fake engage and run, you are good at kiting so you should be able to do this with ease. Fake engage is basically my term for wasting the enemies time. Its that stand still point in team fights where people are debating who goes in first. You want to fake engage close to your turret . Takes 3-4 people to do this while one of your guys split pushes. The split push causes enemy team to send 2-3 guys back to take care of this person, that leaves a strong balance for you folks to push lanes.

Bronze is all about thinking what can I do to help us get one step closer to the nexus without depending on my team.

Early game is crucial in bronze to see who cooperates and who doesnt. If someone doesnt respond to ganks or team fights, dont team fight and blame them, You know they are trash. Dont think anything is going to change in that less than an hour game. 

One of the biggest roles that has an overall map influence is mid lane. The midlane is able to roam, assassinate adcs (usually) . Top lane has limited power. 



To be honest the reason I Take volibear in bronze is I can gank, flip, attack, bite. He is tanky and does alot of damage early game, Even if your laner doesnt respond to your ganks, you can be efficient. His wave clear isnt bad. And he can be built in multiple ways.

When I play volibear, I start at golems/rocks, finish red, if the enemy laner is zoning my laner to his turret, I gank and kill that guy. 

And after that guy comes back, I gank him again and try to kill him again, and at this point that butthead is tilted as fuck. So I farm a little and gank him again.
But I main adc Caitlyn and support Morgana/Brand/Soraka. >_>
Because if I play a champ enough I like to make them look prettier.

I have every champion I want for starter.

And I'm financial comfortable enough to get skins without having to worry about drawbacks.
My question is why would you buy a skin if you can play the champ for free anyways.

Riot needs money from somewhere.

Personally I would feel bad if I spent less than 60 bucks on the game.

As it is, my routine is to spend one hundred per year on the game, because I appreciate it. I currently have about 16 thousand RP sitting unused. I'll buy RP only when the RP is on sale, and spend it only when something I want is on sale.
You shouldnt feel bad about spending money on a game for free
The game cost money to create, update, and operate. I want the game to continue. So I gave Riot some money. Seems totally reasonable.

It takes hours to earn him through IP, yes. However, people don't just have the game and sit around doing nothing. Tristana, Garen, and Alistar are free champions through the social media outlets. At one point, the starter pack was available for free on Amazon, and it included all of the 450 IP champs at the time, champs such as Annie, Ashe, Master Yi, and Sivir. On top of that, there's also the free champion rotation.  So if you're starting the game, you have quite an opportunity to gain champions to learn the basics of the game with, and should you require a different champion, you will be earning the IP to buy those champions as you play the game. And you'll always play the game, so you will always be earning IP. 
On top of that, at current, if you wanted to take Ranked by storm, you absolutely can with some of the bottom of the barrel champions. Garen, Ashe, Sivir, Soraka, Ryze, and Kayle are all very solid picks and very simple to master, so it's not like you'll have this burning need to dump them and pick up different champions in order to progress through the game. So earning IP for expensive champions isn't so much a hassle as you make it out to be, considering how easy it is to earn and the lack of an immediate necessity to replace the starter champions with the expensive ones. You can easily be content with any of the starter champs as you work your way through the game, and you can use your money to buy skins, rather than fall for the noob trap of buying something you can very easily earn for free with a bit of time playing the game.

It's part of a hobby and game immersion. For some, buying skins is worth it for the feeling of satisfaction they get. 

Take World of Warcraft, for example, players buy digital stuffs hard core on that game from a few bucks $ to $$$$$$$$ for an in-game item.
I undrstand people spend lots of real money on video games, I am referring to this as a whole though

You play your game and spend your money your way, I'll spend my money my way. I think its wasteful to spend money on champions because you can get them through playing the game, something you'll be doing anyway. You generally won't get skins as frequently as you will champions  (due to Hextech being a slower process), and a skin on sale has more merit than a champion on sale on account of the difficulty in obtaining skins. 
I understand this is most likely a troll post, but you really don't take into consideration why people would enjoy seeing different spins on a character they love to play as something they want to put money into.

Its not the question of a game, but how you make your financial decisions in life. 

It takes hours on end to purchase a champion. Something you can actually utilize

I like how they look and want to support the developers of a game I enjoy.

It's as simple as that.

People like the idea of customization in games.  This game happens to charge players for it, but if you consider the cost to be worth it, then there isn't a problem.  And the more players spend, the more Riot can do for the players.  It's basic economics!

I buy skins.  Well, mostly I buy mystery skins.  Looking back, I wish I hadn't spent as much because a lot of those skins are for champs I don't play as much, but I love the random aspect.  It's basic gambling!
